Name: Andrea Olaizola
Bio: I'm currently majoring in chemistry and biology at UBC. I've always been passionate about design, technology and medicine. What motivates me the most is being able to contribute in the development of innovative and more efficient technologies to improve healthcare and quality of life. I'm excited to work with BEST and learn more about the biomedical industry.

Name: Bianca Kirsh
Bio: Innovations and research in the field of medicine were what first drew me to engineering and BEST. Nonetheless, the community's passion, dedication, and commitment to creating impactful change are what truly keep me motivated  and excited about the future. I am a third-year BMEG student in the Cellular Bioengineering stream and my passions include epigenetics, biohacking, and treatment of genetic diseases.  Currently, I work as a Research Assistant at BCCHR where I study rare genetic disorders in children.

Name: Jessica Yamamoto
Bio: As a Chemical Engineering student, I always aim to be multidisciplinary and learn as much as I can! The Biomedical field always astounds me with its new innovations and ways to help people globally and I am excited to be a part of it. I aim to learn new software skills on BEST, like MATLAB, to allow me to analyze data and arrive at the best solution for our client's needs.

Name: Meriem Satra
Bio: Being part of BEST for the past two years has been amazing! As a Biomedical Engineering student, I am interested in all the interdisciplinary integration of innovative technology, and the health field to create an easier life for everyone. BEST has allowed me the opportunity to work with like-minded, passionate and hard-working individuals on projects where we are able to apply our knowledge and our interests to give back to our community.

Name: Rana Ahmed Barghout
Bio: My name is Rana and I'm a third year CHBE student. This is my 3rd year in BEST but I just started out with BIT this summer, as I was very interested in pursuing a CHBE focused project! I'm very interested in the biotech, pharma, and biomedical industries.

Name: Ali Jamal
Bio: I am excited to be a part of Enable because designing assistive devices for individuals with disabilities aligns directly with my passion. I have always had an ethic of service, which makes UBC BEST a perfect fit for me. I have experience in engineering design through technical projects and co-op work terms.

Name: Arito Wada
Bio: With my background working in the medical device manufacturing industry, I hope to use the skills I learned to develop solutions for clients requiring assistive technology in their everyday lives.

Name: Brock Wiebe
Bio: I have a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering Technology from SAIT in Calgary Alberta. I learnt from this experience that engineers can make in incredible impact on people's lives. There is no better opportunity at UBC other then BEST to do this.

Name: Coralie Tcheune
Bio: The rush of excitement that comes from tackling biomedical problems is one I have never encountered until joining UBC BEST. In only my first two years of university, I have helped to develop medical devices from concept generation all the way to the final product. My current goal is to continue innovating easily reproducible assistive devices while building my mechanical and electrical skills. After graduation, I aspire to become an orthopedic surgeon. In my free time, I study, forget to sleep, study some more, and if I'm feeling really wild, I'll write stories that I convince myself I'll publish someday.

Name: Dannon Sturn
Bio: I love helping people and have been drawn to BEST because of the amazing opportunities to improve the lives of others. My passion for learning has led me to explore many different disciplines. On the ENABLE sub-team of BEST I have worked on diverse projects, and have been able to develop a diverse set of skills. After graduation, I am hoping to work in surgical robotics!

Name: Fabiola Martens
Bio: I am fascinated by the human body, particularly the biomechanics and physiological functions that optimize our ability to interact with and adapt to the world around us. As someone with a knack for understanding mechanical systems, an appreciation for electronics and software, and a drive to improve compromised health, I aim to contribute to the development of innovative biomedical engineering products and services which do just that.

Name: Jaden Coelho
Bio: I've always been interested in engineering and creating new things and my love for the human bodying and helping others has led me to the biomedical aspect of engineering.

Name: Jamie Yuen
Bio: My diverse engineering co-op and project experience has helped me develop various mechanical, electrical, and programming skills, which has been especially useful in previous design challenges and multi-disciplinary events. Working towards my minor in Psychology has also given me perspective into how external and biological factors interact and affect individual and collectivistic psychological facets, potentially inducing changes in physical well-being. I aspire to use my unique breadth of competence to help others live normal lives, unaffected by disabilities or illnesses.

Name: Joshua French
Bio: I believe the intersection of medicine, engineering, and innovation has the enormous potential to better lives. This belief is the primary driver behind my academic and extracurricular pursuits.  I have experience as a Research Assistant at the Centre for Hip Health and Mobility, located at VGH. Additionally, I am pursuing a Minor in Entrepreneurship and placed third in the Innovation OnBoard Competition with the UBC Biomod team; our project being a system for the early detection of lung cancer.  www.linkedin.com/in/joshfrenchubc

Name: Nima Yazdi
Bio: I joined BEST in my second year at UBC. Throughout this time I've had the opportunity to work on exciting projects that have a tangible impact on the lives of others while also gaining experience with biomedical devices at companies such as Kardium Inc. and Heart Force. I chose the biomedical option because of my passion to design and create with the purpose of helping others, and I hope to continue working in the biomedical field in the future.

Name: Nozomi Asaoka
Bio: I love how biomedical engineering strives to resolve prevalent medical issues using engineering problem-solving approaches. In first-year, I initially joined BEST as a mentee on ENABLE, and the experience opened my eyes to the vast scope of biomedical engineering. I learned a lot from my mentors and peers on BEST, and am excited to continue my journey on ENABLE and keep working on assistive device projects!

Name: Alessandro Narciso
Bio: Ever since I first became interested in engineering, the innovations that astounded me the most were the biomedical ones. The concept of being able to save someone's life or improve it through biomedical innovations was so inspiring to me. This drove me to join BEST in the beginning of my first year at UBC and I have been a member of the club ever since. I am currently finishing my fourth year of Electrical Engineering.  When first joining BEST, I was member of the Infectious Disease Emergency Aid - Electronic Medical Records System Project (IDEA-EMR) where I worked on designing and testing the user interface. After the project was completed, I was a member of the Respiratory Rate Monitor Project where I worked on troubleshooting and developing the prototype code. I later then transitioned to the Chief Operations Officer role, and am now serving as BEST's Chief Executive Officer.  My work experience consists of 3 work terms, one with the Government of Alberta, Department of Economic Development and Trade, where I aided my team in marketing Albertan corporations to attract foreign investment. I also worked with Dynamic Attractions where I worked with robotics to develop ride vehicle systems for the entertainment industry. I also worked as an ICT Engineering Intern with Huawei Technologies, working with mobile/computer networking technologies, artificial intelligence, cloud computing, and 5G.  Being a part of BEST has been the highlight of my university career. BEST has given me the chance to develop my technical skills for the past 4 years and I hope to keep contributing to the club's success by taking on the role of CEO. It is so exciting to be a part of such a talented and driven group of students who are changing the world through biomedical innovation.

Name: Andrew Yan
Bio: I was initially attracted to biomedical engineering and UBC BEST because it combines my two passions, Medicine and Engineering. I had the opportunity to join BEST in my first year at UBC (2015) within the first iteration of the Mentorship Program. At this point in time, I have completed my third year of Electrical Engineering in the Biomedical Option.  When I joined BEST in 2015, my first 4 months with the team were spent doing the non-technical position of Events Coordinator. In January 2016, the first iteration of the mentorship program began and I got to become a member of IDEA-EMR, a project that finished that May of that same year. While on IDEA-EMR, I got the chance to apply some of my Java knowledge to help develop the user interface for the app. Following the completion of IDEA-EMR, I worked with the Music to Movement project developing one of the first software interfaces, as well as designing some of the peripheral internal circuitry.  I have had two co-op experiences so far at UBC, and am currently on my third. My first co-op was with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering for 4 months, where I got to develop skills with WordPress and Altium Designer. My second co-op was 8 months with Intel Corporation, where I was a part of a team developing error correction code algorithms for an upcoming product. I am currently working my third co-op at Kardium Inc., a local biotechnology company.  I am excited to be CTO of BEST, not only because I get to lead such a diverse and talented group of students, but also because I hope to continue to develop and grow impactful and innovative projects, much like my predecessors in this role.

Name: Emma Gray
Bio: After two years with our Medical Innovation in Neurotechnology (MINT) team, I'm thrilled to be joining the BEST executives this year as COO.  I've always known that I wanted to pursue a creative, challenging and rewarding career that allowed me to help people. However, joining BEST allowed me to realize those goals much earlier than expected.  This team has offered me the opportunity to tackle real-world problems from an engineering perspective, and to witness student projects grow from ideas to fully-fledged devices that help people every day. That's one of the many reasons that it's a privilege to help represent the curious, passionate and talented students that make up this team.  I'm currently in my third year of school, studying Engineering Physics. My biomedical work experience consists of 8 months across two labs in the biomedical research field, with the first focusing on functional neuroimaging and the second on biomechanics and measurements from topographical indices.  This Spring, I'm working as a Product Design Engineering Co-op at MistyWest, a Vancouver-based engineering consultancy that has developed numerous medical devices.

Name: Jackson Robinson
Bio: I am a current Mechanical Engineering student with a Biomedical specialization. I have a strong passion for improving medical practice in developing countries, and am very excited to contribute to device development as a project lead of FFTP. My professional interests include biomechanics and numerical analysis, with previous experience working in the engineering consulting industry. When not at school, I spend time working as a skating instructor, hiking and playing guitar, and hope to successfully apply to a Canadian medical school upon graduation.

Name: Aahana Kanyal
Bio: I joined BEST to enhance my research experience as a biomedical engineer and make a difference in the lives of stroke survivors. I am excited to further my skills as an engineer and to make a difference in rehabilitating stroke survivors.

Name: Allison Simpson
Bio: Hello! I joined the BEST Mentee program in my first year at UBC to gain experience in the Biomed. field, and contribute to developing accessible medical devices. Currently, I am a full member of M2M and my role on the team involves integrating mechanical and electrical components into our prototypes. I am excited for our meetings each week, knowing that I can develop my skills as an engineering student to improve overall health and treatment outcomes for stroke survivors!

Name: Angelica Liaw
Bio: I am an Electrical Engineering student with Biomedical specialization who is passionate about learning how things work, and applying engineering knowledge towards creating innovative and practical designs in the biomedical sector. I am excited to lead this diverse group of students to continue progressing the M2M project and see it move closer to helping people with their rehabilitation process. When I am not submerged in work, I enjoy watching movies, going to the beach or sewing.
Management Bio: I am an Electrical Engineering student with Biomedical specialization who is passionate about learning how things work, and applying engineering knowledge towards creating innovative and practical designs in the biomedical sector. I am excited to lead this diverse group of students to continue progressing the M2M project and see it move closer to helping people with their rehabilitation process. When I am not submerged in work, I enjoy watching movies, going to the beach or sewing.

Name: Tony Lee
Bio: I have always been interested in the biomedical/medical field, which Music 2 Movement has been proving me an opportunity to delve into. It's great that I can help out the team through my code and contribute to creating assistive devices that can help stroke patients!

Name: Laia Shpeller
Bio: My career goal is to make health care more accessible to those in less developed countries as well as those in isolated communities within more developed countries. I have experience working in a biomedical systems and signals lab developing Alzheimer's treatments through the University of Manitoba and have been a member of BEST/MAST since 2018. I am enthusiastic about continuing to develop my coding skills and learn more about client interactions this upcoming year on MAST!

Name: Lisa Kirby
Bio: It is a life-long goal to eventually end up working in Global Health, so I am extremely excited to have the opportunity to work on the Respiratory Rate Monitor project with such bright teammates. I have experience working as a web applications developer for the Canadian Federal Government and enjoy developing everything from low-level FPGA hardware to high-level software for web and mobile applications. In my spare time, I love studying the brain, reading biographies, and eating good food.

Name: Alex Wen
Bio: Fundamentally, I like solving interesting problems! I'm eager to see how effective data analysis and machine learning can further improve medical technology, and give us powerful, life-changing, tools and abilities.  My background is in experimental physics, and I've worked on large-scale particle physics experiments like ATLAS and LHCb, and at labs like TRIUMF and SNOLAB. I hope to go to graduate school for physics and remain in academic research.

Name: Ardin Sacayanan
Bio: I'm excited and eager to combine knowledge from previous chemical engineering and current biomedical engineering courses to create solutions that has the potential to improve the quality of life for everyone. I aspire to work in a hospital one day, designing devices that could deliver high-quality healthcare to patients of all sorts.

Name: Atoosa Mahmoudian
Bio: I am very passionate about creating designs and seeing them come to life using 3D printing. In my designs, I always seek for inspiration in nature as I find the concept of biomimicry very interesting. As a part of the mechanical subteam, I work with CAD software and 3D printers to help develop an awesome EEG headset!

Name: Bruno Ozaki
Bio: I have always been interested in working with new technologies and creating new things. This combined with my passion for helping people made me choose biomedical engineering. More specifically, I hope to be working in the areas of neurotechnology or imaging and am really excited to be part of MINT.

Name: Daniel Luo
Bio: I joined BEST because of the quality of the projects and the focus on tackling key challenges in the health sector. Prior to joining BEST I have been highly involved in UBC Unmanned Aircraft Systems where I developed hardware for unmanned drones using SolidWorks and rapid prototyping tools. As part of the Medical Innovation in NeuroTechnology Project, I am researching and developing an electrode that can acquire high quality brain signals.

Name: Hamza Peracha
Bio: BEST is a great opportunity for me to learn more about biomedical engineering in a more hands on manner.

Name: Han Nguyen
Bio: My passion is brain-computer interface. I want to help humans brain-control all kinds of machines.

Name: Joshua Park
Bio: I joined BEST to combine my passions in biomedical and software engineering. Here I am able to translate real problems into viable solutions using both of these skills!

Name: Natalia Gosnell
Bio: I'm passionate about neurotechnology, mechanics, and cellular bioengineering! I have extensive SolidWorks experience and an enthusiasm for design.

Name: Nicholas Winship
Bio: I am passionate about electronics and actively look for ways to challenge my technical and personal skills through design and collaboration. I have experience working as an Engineering Product Design Co-op in Mechatronics at Dometic, a Vancouver-based Engineering firm that develops steering control-systems. As I have a desire to work with technology and medicine, the biomedical field seemed like the perfect place to meld my interests. Thus, I am thrilled to be joining BEST as part of the MINT team.

Name: Riley Zurrin
Bio: Hello!  I've been interested in math and theoretical physics since I was young and I'm excited to continue extending these frameworks into the engineering world. I have experience analyzing functional MRI data and am glad to begin analyzing EEG data in order to progress the domain of neurotechnology. My hobbies include reading, playing tennis, and playing hockey! I hope to get accepted into a medical school after my undergraduate degree and eventually practice either radiology or neurological surgery.

Name: Wenting Zhou
Bio: As a third-generation UBC student, I am excited to be studying Biomedical Engineering at UBC. My involvement with BEST has provided me with the opportunity to learn, develop technical skills, and connect with fellow students and professionals in the biomedical community. My passion for biomedical engineering is driven by an interest in anatomical systems and enthusiasm for problem-solving and design. Beyond my studies and BEST, I enjoy playing hockey and spending time with my dog.
Management Bio: While pursuing a degree in Biomedical Engineering, my involvement with BEST has allowed me to also follow my interest in designing innovative solutions to medical problems. As a BEST mentee in my first year of studies, I was inspired to start and lead a new project team focused on making an impact locally. Not only am I gaining experience in the technical aspects of project development with UBC Uplift, I am also developing leadership and management skills as project lead. Biomedical engineering offers the unique opportunity to be creative and curious, explore new ways to help people, and make positive change. In being able to collaborate with my teammates, connect with clients, and see the impact of our work in the community, I'm even more excited to continue learning and working towards making a meaningful contribution as a biomedical engineer.

Name: Danika Unger
Bio: I am a second year Integrated Engineering student with a passion for the intersection between medicine and engineering. I am interested in project management and the engineering consulting industry. BEST allows me to gain valuable technical knowledge and offers me the opportunity to develop my leadership skills - contributing to both my personal and professional growth.
Management Bio: I am a second year Integrated Engineering student with a passion for the intersection between medicine and engineering. I am interested in project management and the engineering consulting industry. BEST allows me to gain valuable technical knowledge and offers me the opportunity to develop my leadership skills - contributing to both my personal and professional growth.

Name: Rebecca Lim
Bio: As a third-generation UBC student, I am excited to be studying at UBC while gaining an enriched learning experience through my involvement with BEST. My passion for biomedical engineering was sparked by an interest in anatomical systems and an affinity for problem-solving and design. My work ethic and curiosity drive my enthusiasm for developing my technical skills and learning about engineering processes through practical applications. Beyond my studies and BEST, I enjoy playing hockey and spending time with my dog.

Name: Abbie Smith
Bio: I am passionate about helping people and eager to learn more about problem solving and design. I am a driven mechanical engineering student and I am interested in pursuing biomechanics and sports medicine. I am so excited to be working with UBC BEST and the Uplift team to make a positive impact on our community!

Name: Matthew Mong
Bio: I am delighted to lead the software team on Uplift as we work to implement a Real Time Operating System and multiple wireless communication protocols. With a background in backend and algorithm design I look forward to further developing my software skills with regards to microcontroller applications.

Name: Patrick Cervantes
Bio: Through Uplift, I have been able to utilize my passion for engineering to directly help a person in need. As someone who is interested in biomechanics, my involvement as a mechanical engineer on this team has reinforced that interest, as it has given me the opportunity to get hands-on experience, whether it is through using SolidWorks or building things in the machine shop. On my free time, I love to play the alto saxophone, hockey, and soccer.

Name: Sara Bortolussi-Courval
Bio: I am in my second year of Integrated Engineering at UBC, majoring in Mechanical and minoring in Biomed. My passion for biomechanics stems from a desire to reinvent assistive devices and exoskeletons to improve people's quality of life. I am looking forward to applying my designing, testing and manufacturing knowledge to help Uplift achieve its goals.

Name: Tina Nguyen
Bio: With a strong interest in electrical systems and signal as well as helping people, I am passionate about developing and implementing creative solutions to medical and health related problems through engineering applications. As a member of BEST Uplift, I hope to be able to gain more technical experience working with electrical components and modules.

Name: Tsu Yuan Wang
Bio: I'm Tsu Yuan. Most people call me by Ewan. I am the type of person who loves trying new things and make the best out of life. I can code like a genius but also party like crazy. I go by the motto, work hard, play harder. So, when I am at work, you can expect laser focus from me. I always make sure I live a balanced life so I can be on my A-game all the time.

Name: Warren Chan Wan Fong
Bio: I have experience with circuit design and theory, and coding experience in various languages such as Python, C and Perl. Working towards a Bachelor of Applied Science in Electrical Engineering (Biomedical Option). Executive member of UBC IEEE and part of the UBC Engineering Co-op Program.

Name: Yazan Al Attar
Bio: I am a third year electrical engineering student and I have a great passion for enhancing or improving people's lives. I aim to fulfill my passion by either directly pursuing biomedical opportunities or indirectly by providing services that improve our society's quality of life.

Name: Angelica Phelan
Bio: I am very excited to be a part of BEST since I have always had a passion for innovation in the medical field and love to contribute to bettering other people's lives.  These interests originated from my experience volunteering at a thermofluidic lab at UBC Okanagan as well as training to become an EMR.

Name: Masih Golbidi
Bio: As someone who has always been excited and inspired by engineering innovations in the biomedical field, I am excited to integrate my own ideas into this field with UBC's Biomedical Engineering Student Team. As a mentee, I hope to learn from my team while integrating my own skills into our project solutions. By applying my knowledge from lectures, labs, and extracurricular activities, I wish to improve the lives of patients with our biomedical solutions.

Name: Nicole Gonin
Bio: I am excited about biomedical engineering and UBC BEST's projects because of the opportunity these provide to make medical assistance accessible to the individual and to the larger global community. During my time with BEST and at UBC, I hope to learn how and in what ways I can help the biomedical community reach these goals. I spend my free time hiking, biking and trying (unsuccessfully) to learn how to cook.

Name: Rae Mazzei
Bio: BEST is an incredible opportunity for me to be emerged into the biomedical community. This team provides a hands-on manner of learning which has expanded my problem-solving techniques as well as pushed me to become more innovative.

Name: Rhea Kaul
Bio: As a first year in engineering I am excited to learn and explore !

Name: Ryan Sutherland-Pace
Bio: Biomedical Engineering has always been an interest to me. I hope to use my experience with robotics and the new skills I learn through BEST to learn more about this field and develop some innovative solutions to prevalent problems in society.

Name: Stephanie Quon
Bio: I am super excited to be part of BEST this year! I hope to gain technical skills through the mentorship program, and learn more about what engineering is and how it can be used to help people.

Name: Vivian Osiek
Bio: I have a passion for biomedical innovation and the connections between medicine and technology. I am interested in exploring biomedical fields such as tissue engineering, assistive devices, and biomaterials. The more I learn, the more I appreciate the ways that technology can be applied to improve quality of life.
